TF092585-PPIAF: TURKEY: PPPS FOR
            RESTRUCTURING OF ISTANBUL SUBSIDIARY ENTERPRISE

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Istanbul Municipal
            Infrastructure Project for Turkey were as follows: outcomes
            were highly unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            high, Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the proactive and consultative approach taken by
            the Borrower, the Guarantor, and the Bank in closing the
            project allowed all parties to manage risk and minimize the
            cost of an unsuccessful project. The need for land
            acquisition and resettlement is often necessary to ensure
            safe development and provide social benefits. In case of a
            major reallocation of resources or significant changes in
            the priority of components through restructuring, a greater
            use of the Bank's internal quality control mechanisms,
            such as a full decision-meeting, and peer reviews will
            likely improve the outcome of the restructuring. While a
            project implementation unit (PIU) management structure may
            have simplified the process of Bank supervision, its
            effectiveness in achieving program development objectives
            (PDO's) and ensuring smooth implementation will still
            have required adequate processes and authority for the PIU
            to interface and coordinate with various implementing
            departments and entities. Projects that support a large
            number of different investments, not all of which may be
            fully identified before appraisal require careful project design.
